metadata.title: Size-dependent nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials including a refined truncated cube cell

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Size-dependent nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials including a refined truncated cube cell
S. Sahmani, M.M. Aghdam
PII: S0375-9601(17)30969-6 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physleta.2017.10.013 Reference: PLA 24775
To appear in: Physics Letters A
Received date: 23 June 2017 Revised date: 3 October 2017 Accepted date: 9 October 2017
Please cite this article in press as: S. Sahmani, M.M. Aghdam, Size-dependent nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials including a refined truncated cube cell, Phys. Lett. A (2017), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physleta.2017.10.013
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Highlights
• Analytical expressions for mechanical properties of nanoporous biomaterials based on a refined truncated cube cell. • Development a nonlocal strain gradient beam model for the size dependent nonlinear bending analysis. • Prediction the influence of pore size and small scale effects on nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous bioma-
terial.
Size-dependent nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous
biomaterials including a refined truncated cube cell
S. Sahmani*, M.M. Aghdam
Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, P.O. Box 15875-4413, Tehran, Iran

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Morphology and pore size plays an essential role in the mechanical properties as well as the associated biological capability of a porous structure made of biomaterials. The objective of the current study is to predict the Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio of nanoporous biomaterials including refined truncated cube cells based on a hyperbolic shear deformable beam model. Analytical relationships for the mechanical properties of nanoporous biomaterials are given as a function of the refined cell's dimensions. After that, the size dependency in the nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beams made of such nanoporous biomaterials is analyzed using the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. It is assumed that the micro/nano-beam has one movable end under axial compression in conjunction with a uniform distributed lateral load. The Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique is employed to propose explicit analytical expression for nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection curves of the micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials subjected to uniform transverse distributed load. It is found that through increment of the pore size, the micro/nano-beam will undergo much more deflection corresponding to a specific distributed load due to the reduction in the stiffness of nanoporous biomaterial. This pattern is more prominent for lower value of applied axial compressive load at the free end of micro/nanobeam.
Keywords: Nanomechanics; Porous biomaterials; Size effect; Nonlinear bending; Nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory.
*Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 21 66405844, Fax: +98 21 66419736. E-mail addresses: sahmani@aut.ac.ir; sasahmani@gmail.com (S. Sahmani).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Because of unique mechanical properties of porous biomaterilas, they are in great demand for a variety of biological applications. The gradual degradation is one of the most important performances of porous biomaterials which makes the possibility of growing tissues in vacant spaces to deposit the prefer matrix. Mour et al. [1] reported the role of porosity in dental applications of porous biomaterials and the influence of pore properties on the living tissues. O'Brien [2] studied about using porous biomaterials in production of scaffold to regenerate various tissues and organs in the body. Zohora and Azim [3] presented an overview on different types of porous biomaterials developed for soft and hard tissues. Zadpoor [4] studied given a collection of various investigations presented different trends in mechanics of porous biomaterials for characterization of biological tissues.
In recent years, through development of material science and technology, nanoporous biomaterials have been attracted much attention for using in biosensing, drug delivery and other types of biomedical application. Gong et al. [5] fabricated nanoporous alumina capsules which are relatively inexpensive and are suitable for biofiltration. Orosz et al. [6] utilized a nanoporous inorganic filter to propose a novel method for delivery of antiangiogenic and antioxidant drugs. Narayan et al. [7] investigated the use of atomic layer deposition for coating the surfaces of membranes made of nanoporous biomaterial.
Nowadays, several micro/nano-structures have been produced and utilized in a variety of technological aspects. In order to make the continuum mechanical applicable in analysis of micro/nano-structures, it needs to take small length scales such as lattice spacing and grain size into account. Up to now, various unconventional continuum theories have been established to consider size dependency in mechanical characteristics of micro/nano-structures [8-26]. According to the previous studies, it has been observed that the nonlocal elasticity theory and strain gradient continuum mechanics represent two entirely different size effects including softening-stiffness and hardeningstiffness influences. To overcome this paradox, Lim et al. [27] developed the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which incorporates simultaneously the both features of size dependency. After that, several investigations have been carried out to analyze size-dependent mechanical behavior of micro/nano-structures. Li and Hu [28] used the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to develop a size-dependent Euler-Bernoulli beam model for buckling analysis of nanobeams. They also formulated the equations related to the wave motion fluid-conveying viscoelastic carbon nanotubes based upon the nonlocal strain gradient continuum mechanics [29]. Simsek [30] examined the sizedependent nonlinear vibrations of functionally graded Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams via nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. Yang et al. [31] studied the nonlocal strain gradient dynamic pull-in instability of functionally graded carbon nanotube-reinforced nano-actuators. Li et al. [32] analyzed the longitudinal vibrations of nano-scaled rods on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Tang et al. [33] predicted the viscoelastic wave propagation in an embedded viscoelastic
carbon nanotube based on the theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity. Ebrahimi and Barati [34] employed the nonlocal strain gradient theory to anticipate damping vibration response of hygrothermally affected functionally graded viscoelastic nanobeams. Xu et al. [35] explored the nonlocal strain gradient bending and buckling of Euler-Bernoulli nanobeams Based on the weighted residual approaches. Sahmani and Aghdam [36] captured size effects on the nonlinear instability of axially loaded microtubules surrounded by cytoplasm based upon the nonlocal strain gradient shell model. Lu et al. [37] proposed a nonlocal strain gradient sinusoidal shear deformable beam model for vibration analysis of nanobeams. Sahmani and Aghdam [38] developed a nonlocal strain gradient shell model for nonlinear instability of magneto-electro-elastic composite nanoshells.
In the current study, at first, a refined form of the analytical approach presented by Hedayati et al. [39] is utilized to predict the elastic modulus and Poisson's ratio of nanoporous biomaterial made from refined truncated cube cell. After that, with the aid of obtained material properties, the size-dependent nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial is analyzed on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity. The micro/nanobeam is supposed to have a movable end under axial compressive load in conjunction with a uniform distributed lateral load. The Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique is employed to propose explicit analytical expression for nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection bending response of micro/nanobeams made of nanoporous biomaterial.

sections.heading: 2. Analytical approach for mechanical properties of nanoporous biomaterials
sections.text:
In this work, it is assumed that a nanoporous biomaterial is made from the refined truncated cube lattice structure as shown in Figure 1. Accordingly, by repeating the cells, a unit cell surrounding by the truncated cubes is achieved, each membrane of which is dedicated to a unique refined truncated cube. It is depicted in Figure 2 that due to the geometrical symmetry, the links and
and and of the unit cell have the same mechanical in-
plane deformations. As a result, analyzing one of them is enough to capture the mechanical response of the unit cell. Here, the link is selected to be analyzed.
Firstly, based upon the refined hyperbolic shear deformable beam model for the links of the unit

The vertices of link do not enable to rotate
The points enable only to displace vertically
The points and displace the same vertically, but different horizontally.
The point is fixed. Accordingly, the degrees of freedom can be related to the associated external
force as below
In order to obtain the elements of the stiffness matrix column by column, the displacements relevant to each degree of freedom are achieved separately in such a way that the related degree of freedom is supposed to be unit and the other ones are zero.

sections.heading: 3. Nonlocal strain gradient beam model for porous micro/nano-beams
sections.text:
According to the hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory, the components of displacement field along different coordinate directions take the following forms
where and represent the displacement components of the micro/nano-beam along x- and z-axis, respectively. Moreover, stands for the rotation relevant to the cross section of nanobeam at neutral plane normal about y-axis. Thus the non-zero strain components can be introduced as
in which denote the mid-plane strain components, is the first-order curvature component,
and is the higher-order curvature component.
As it has been reported in specialized literature on the subject of size dependency, it has been indicated that small scale effects may cause two entirely different influences incorporating hardeningstiffness or stiffening-stiffness features. Motivated by this fact, Lim et al. [27] proposed a new unconventional continuum theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory which contains the both nonlocal and strain gradient size effects simultaneously. As a result, the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor for a beam-type structure can be expressed as below [27]
where and are the stress and higher-order stress tensors, respectively, which can be expressed as
in which is the elastic matrix, and are, respectively, the principal attenuation kernel function including the nonlocality and the additional kernel function associated with the nonlocality effect of the first-order strain gradient field, and in order represent a point and any point else in the body, and stands for the internal strain gradient length scale parameter. Following the method of Eringen, the constitutive relationship corresponding to the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor of a beamtype structure can be obtained as
where denotes the nonlocal parameter. Therefore, the nonlocal strain gradient constitutive relations for a hyperbolic shear deformable micro/nano-beam made of nanoporous biomaterial can be expressed as

sections.heading: 5. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this section, some numerical results are given for the size-dependent nonlinear bending characteristics of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial with different pore sizes. It is assumed that the biomaterial is made from Ti6Al4V-ELI Titanium alloy having an elastic modulus of
, and Poisson's ratio of [46]. Also, the geometrical parameter of the
micro/nano-beam are selected as: . Additionally, the links of the refined truncated cubic cells has a circular cross section with radius of .
Firstly, the validity and accuracy of the developed solution methodology are checked. To this end, by ignoring the nonlinear and strain gradient terms, the nonlocal maximum deflection of a clampedsimply-supported isotropic nanobeam under uniform distributed load is obtained corresponding to different nonlocal parameters and compared with those reported by Ghannadpour et al. [47] using Ritz method. As it is tabulated in Table 1, a very good agreement is found which confirms the accuracy of the present solving process.
Figures 4 and 5 depict the nonlocal strain gradient dimensionless load-deflection response of the nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial corresponding to different values of small scale parameters. It can be seen that by taking nonlocality into account, the stiffness of micro/nano-beam reduces as at a specific value of the distributed load, more deflection is induced in the micro/nano-beam. However, the strain gradient size dependency plays an opposite role, and it enhances the stiffness of micro/nano-beam which leads to less deflection for a specific distributed load. Furthermore, it is indicated that by increasing the value of applied axial compression at the movable end of micro/nano-beam, the influence of the both types of size effect becomes more significant, especially for the nonlocal size effect.
In Figure 6, the load-deflection response of the nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial is illustrated corresponding to various pore sizes (different aspect ratios of the refined truncated cube's links). It can be found that through increment of the pore size (higher value of
), the micro/nano-beam will undergo much more deflection corresponding to a specific distributed load due to the reduction in the stiffness of nanoporous biomaterial. This pattern is more prominent for lower value of applied axial compressive load at the free end of micro/nano-beam.
Figures 7 and 8 demonstrate, respectively, the influence of nonlocality and strain gradient size dependency on the nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial
corresponding to different pore sizes (various aspect ratios of the refined truncated cube's links). It can be observed that by applied higher axial compressive load to the free end of the micro/nano-beam, the influence of the pore size on the load-deflection response decreases, the micro/nano-beam undergoes more deflection, and the gap between the size-independent and size-dependent paths becomes more significant.
In Tables 2 and 3, the size-dependent nonlinear bending characteristics of micro/nano-beams made of the nanoporous biomaterial are presented in more details corresponding to various values of nonlocal parameter and strain gradient parameter, respectively, and for different pore sizes. The percentages given in parentheses indicate the amount of the reduction or increment due to the size effect. It is revealed that at higher maximum deflection, the influence of the both types of size effect on the nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beam decreases. However, this anticipation is more considerable for the nonlocal size dependency in comparison with the strain gradient one. Moreover, it is seen that for all pore sizes and all values of maximum deflection, the strain gradient size effect plays more significant role in the nonlinear bending behavior than the nonlocal one with the same value of the small scale parameter. This pattern is more prominent corresponding to lower axial compression applied to the free end of micro/nano-beam. Also, it is found that the pore size (the value of ) has no influence on the significance of the both size dependencies.

sections.heading: 6. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
The objective of this work was to explore the size-dependent nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterial. For this purpose, at first, the elastic mechanical properties of the nanoporous biomaterial were predicted in terms of the pore size based upon a refined truncated cube cells. After that, the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory was implemented into the hyperbolic shear deformation beam theory to construct a size-dependent beam model incorporating two entirely different size effects. The Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique was employed to propose explicit analytical expression for the nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection response of the nonlinear bending of micro/nano-beams made of a nanoporous biomaterial.
It was revealed that by taking nonlocality into account, the stiffness of micro/nano-beam reduces, while the strain gradient size dependency plays an opposite role, and it enhances the stiffness of micro/nano-beam. It was shown that by increasing the value of applied axial compression at the movable end of micro/nano-beam, the influence of the both types of size effect becomes more significant, especially for the nonlocal size effect. Furthermore, it was observed that through increment of the pore size (higher value of ), the micro/nano-beam will undergo much more deflection corresponding to a specific distributed load due to the reduction in the stiffness of nanoporous biomaterial. This pattern is more prominent for lower value of applied axial compressive
load at the free end of micro/nano-beam. In addition, it was seen that at higher maximum deflection, the influence of the both types of size effect on the nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beam decreases. Also, for all pore sizes and all values of maximum deflection, the strain gradient size effect plays more significant role in the nonlinear bending behavior than the nonlocal one with the same value of the small scale parameter. Finally, it was indicated that the pore size has no influence on the significance of the both size dependencies.

metadata.abstractText: Morphology and pore size plays an essential role in the mechanical properties as well as the associated biological capability of a porous structure made of biomaterials. The objective of the current study is to predict the Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio of nanoporous biomaterials including refined truncated cube cells based on a hyperbolic shear deformable beam model. Analytical relationships for the mechanical properties of nanoporous biomaterials are given as a function of the refined cell's dimensions. After that, the size dependency in the nonlinear bending behavior of micro/nano-beams made of such nanoporous biomaterials is analyzed using the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. It is assumed that the micro/nano-beam has one movable end under axial compression in conjunction with a uniform distributed lateral load. The Galerkin method together with an improved perturbation technique is employed to propose explicit analytical expression for nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection curves of the micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials subjected to uniform transverse distributed load. It is found that through increment of the pore size, the micro/nano-beam will undergo much more deflection corresponding to a specific distributed load due to the reduction in the stiffness of nanoporous biomaterial. This pattern is more prominent for lower value of applied axial compressive load at the free end of micro/nanobeam.
